content: >http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/iraq-air-raids-hit-mostly-women-and-children-1669282.html British sources are again criticizing the use of airpower in Iraq and Afghanistan. They claim air attacks inflict unduly large civilian casualties and are a negative in the effort to develop trust, confidence and cooperation in the native population. Since 2001 the USAF has dropped over 14 000 tonnes of bombs on Afghan targets and 18 000 on Iraq. The USAF reports flying on average 140 tactical air missions over Iraq, and double that over Afghanistan, every week. This message has been edited. Last edited by: popsiq, Sun 19 April 2009 02:11 PM
reply: >http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/iraq-air-raids-hit-mostly-women-and-children-1669282.html British sources are again criticizing the use of airpower in Iraq and Afghanistan. They claim air attacks inflict unduly large civilian casualties and are a negative in the effort to develop trust, confidence and cooperation in the native population. Since 2001 the USAF has dropped over 14 000 tonnes of bombs on Afghan targets and 18 000 on Iraq. The USAF reports flying on average 140 tactical air missions over Iraq, and double that over Afghanistan, every week. This message has been edited. Last edited by: popsiq, Sun 19 April 2009 02:11 PM

content: The British could always stop requesting US Airstrikes for their Operations. Also a TAC Air mission is a Sortie, doesnt mean they always drop the load. I had to decline one once when a Pair of F-16's wanted to support us just outside Baghdad. A Bongo Truck had fled after its occupants had executed several workers. We were vectoring assests when the zoomies cut in wanting to drop 750lb'rs. We went with the KW option instead

content: Hey, at least we aren't carpet bombing like we did in WWII (I think the Brits are quite familiar with both sides of the coin when talking about that method). In war, there will always be civilian casualties, you cannot avoid that. But, I will say that the US has been more successful than any other country in history at keeping civilian casualties to a minimum. In war, you cannot please everybody. But, you must still complete the mission. That is just the way it is.

content: quote: Originally posted by 10tenths: Hey, at least we aren't carpet bombing like we did in WWII (I think the Brits are quite familiar with both sides of the coin when talking about that method). In war, there will always be civilian casualties, you cannot avoid that. But, I will say that the US has been more successful than any other country in history at keeping civilian casualties to a minimum. In war, you cannot please everybody. But, you must still complete the mission. That is just the way it is. More successful except in comparison to any other countries that don't drop bombs in the first place. Once again the observation is subjective. It's like the Japanese patting themselves on the back for only killing a milkman, a paperboy and a waitress on her way to work, while attacking the base at Pearl Harbor and killing 2500 military personnel. Precision bombing Afghanistan is only slightly more intelligent than carpet bombing the place -neither has been particularly effective, and, as the Brits are saying, might be making the situation worse. content: quote: Originally posted by LineDoggie: The British could always stop requesting US Airstrikes for their Operations. Also a TAC Air mission is a Sortie, doesnt mean they always drop the load. I had to decline one once when a Pair of F-16's wanted to support us just outside Baghdad. You rarely hear of it, because you rarely hear of the RAF performing such Missions in the first Place. Any idea as to Numbers of RAF Fighterbombers dedicated to the theater? At one point they had a Grand total of 7 Harriers available for service in Afghanistan, thats not even a Full Strength Squadron by RAF Standards. By Default the CAS Fixed Wing mission goes to US Air Assets just by sheer weight of numbers. 7 planes that each can take aloft 4 tons It's not the RAF's fault, their Government has hamstrung them. There are Chinooks(CH-47) sitting in the UK desperately needed in Afghanistan awaiting Insrumentation to be fitted for the last several years.
